column4: yep sethk, but as far as i know could be that the filesystem header was different that the real one (0xfd for software raid) and i think that software like gpart canno scan for this
that's possible.  It would be easy enough to change that byte, and also easy to look at it.
the problem is that i don't have the partition listed no more
yes, I know, but if you know where the partition was (the starting and ending sectors) the partition table is easy to fix
how can i fix it? because gpart was not able to list me useful partitions (just old ones)
you dump the mbr and use a hex editor
the partitions are the last four groups of 16 bytes in the mbr
you can also use fdisk to fix it
you can use fdisk to create the partition.  you give it the starting and ending sector numbers.  fdisk does not touch the partition, only the partition table in the mbr.
could you please tell me some of these commands?
that's of course a problem.  if the rest of the partition table is intact, then you can figure out the starting and ending sectors
say partition one ends at 1000, and partition three starts at 2000, then you would know that partition 2 starts at 1001 and ends at 1999.
obviously I made those numbers up, but you get the idea, hopefully
the problem is that more the one partition is missing, that's why i tried scanning the drive with gpart
and gpart didn't find all the partitions except one?
gpart did not find anything of the latest partitions, just old configuration
too bad.  then you are down to scanning yourself.  I have some programs I wrote to scan, but to use them you would need to know the signatures used in the software raid file system.
I'm a bit surprised that the partition doesn't appear to be a normal linux partition to software unaware of software raid
but as I said I'm no expert on software raid
